SubTopics: Write and evaluate numerical expressions, with and without grouping symbols, involving whole-number exponents.
Content: What is the value of (5^2 - 10) ÷ 5 × 2³?

SubTopics: Apply and extend previous understandings of decimals to develop and fluently use the standard algorithms for addition, subtraction, multiplication and division of decimals.
Content: Paul had a job during his summer vacation. He earned $8.75 per hour. He worked 20 hours per week for 8 weeks. How much money did Paul earn?

SubTopics: Apply the properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions without exponents.
Content: Which expression is equivalent to 25x - 10y?

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by writing and solving equations.
Content: Jim and Ed are debating the answer to the equation 2m3 = 1/4.

:ibox:• Jim states that m is equal to 2 2/3.

• Ed states that m is equal to 3/8.
Which statement is true?

A.Choice: Jim's answer of 2 2/3 is correct because he divided 2/3 by 1/4 to get his answer.

B.Choice: Jim's answer of 2 2/3 is correct because he divided 1/4 by 2/3 to get his answer.

C.Choice: Ed's answer of 3/8 is correct because he multiplied 1/4 by 2/3 to get his answer.

D.Choice: Ed's answer of 3/8 is correct because he divided 1/4 by 2/3 to get his answer.

SubTopics: Use visual models and common denominators.
Content: Jamal will cut a piece of wood that is 2 1/2 feet long into 1/4 -foot sections. How many sections will result?

SubTopics: Represent and analyze quantitative relationships.
Content: Tonya pays $300 each month to rent an office where she earns $25 per hour tutoring students. Which equation represents Tonya's profit, y, for working x hours?

SubTopics: Display numerical data in plots on a number line.
Content: The table represents the number of runs scored by several baseball teams during a season.
problems/NC18G6M/media/7a.jpg
Which box plot correctly represents the data from the table?

SubTopics: Recognize that when two ordered pairs differ only by signs, the locations of the points are related by reflections across one or both axes.
Content: Which ordered pair represents a reflection of the point (-3, 5) across the `text(y)`-axis?

SubTopics: Interpret statements of inequality as statements about the relative position of two numbers on a number line diagram.
Content: Which statement is true?

SubTopics: Reason about inequalities.
Content: Andy runs the same number of miles, x, every week. His total distance run each week is less than 60 miles. Which inequality represents how many miles Andy runs each week?

SubTopics: Write, read, and evaluate algebraic expressions.
Content: What is the value of (5r + 1/5)^2 when r = 0?

SubTopics: Fluently divide using long division with a minimum of a four-digit dividend and interpret the quotient and remainder in context.
Content: During a weekend, the manager of a mall gave away gift cards to every 80th person who visited the mall.

:ibox:• On Saturday, 1,210 people visited the mall.

• On Sunday, 1,814 people visited the mall.
How many people received a gift card?

SubTopics: Apply and extend previous understandings of decimals to develop and fluently use the standard algorithms for addition, subtraction, multiplication and division of decimals.
Content: Jenny bought gas for her car.

:ibox:• Gas cost $3.45 per gallon.

• Jenny bought 12.2 gallons.
What was the total cost for Jenny's gas?
Express the answer as dollars.cents.

SubTopics: Write and evaluate numerical expressions, with and without grouping symbols, involving whole-number exponents.
Content: What is the value of 1,608 ÷ 10³?

SubTopics: Use visual models and common denominators.
Content: Steve has 2 1/2 cups of flour. One of his recipes requires 1/8 cup of flour. What is the maximum number of times Steve can complete the recipe?

SubTopics: Use ratio reasoning with equivalent whole-number ratios to solve real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: An airplane travels at a constant speed of 320 miles per hour. How far, in miles, will the airplane travel in 15 minutes?

SubTopics: Use visual models and common denominators.
Content: Ryan is building a tree house. It will take 85 1/4 hours to complete. He can work on the tree house 15 1/2 hours each week. To the nearest tenth, how many weeks will it take Ryan to complete the tree house?

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by writing and solving equations.
Content: What is the value of x when x/3 = 9 1/3?

SubTopics: Use ratio reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems with percents.
Content: Jenny has finished 12 of the 20 lessons in her piano book. Liam has finished the same percent of lessons from his piano book. His book contains 30 lessons. How many lessons has Liam finished?

SubTopics: Write, read, and evaluate algebraic expressions.
Content: Sam is using the expression m/8n in class. What is the value of the expression when m = 4 and n = 1/2?

SubTopics: Create geometric models to solve real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: What is the area of the pentagon shown below?
problems/NC18G6M/media/21a.jpg

SubTopics: Represent right prisms and right pyramids using nets made up of rectangles and triangles, and use the nets to find the surface area of these figures. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: A net of a three-dimensional figure is shown.
problems/NC18G6M/media/22a.jpg
What is the surface area of the three-dimensional figure?

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by graphing points in all four quadrants of the coordinate plane. Include use of coordinates and absolute value to find distances between points with the same first coordinate or the same second coordinate.
Content: The graph shows segment FG and point P.
problems/NC18G6M/media/23a.jpg

:ibox:• Point M is located in the third quadrant.

• The distance between point M and point P is half the distance between point F and point G.

• Segment MP is parallel to segment FG.
What is the first coordinate of point M?

SubTopics: Understand the concept of a ratio and use ratio language.
Content: There are 4 trucks for every 5 cars in a parking lot. How many trucks and cars could be in the parking lot?

SubTopics: Represent right prisms and right pyramids using nets made up of rectangles and triangles, and use the nets to find the surface area of these figures. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: Suzy is wrapping a cube-shaped box and wants to make sure she has enough wrapping paper. The net for the box is shown.
problems/NC18G6M/media/25a.jpg
What is the area she needs to cover?

SubTopics: Analyze center and variability.
Content: Jamal scored 62, 75, 76, and 90 on four tests. What does he need to score on the fifth test in order to have a mean of exactly 80?

SubTopics: Use ratio reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems with percents.
Content: Seventy-five 6th-grade students chose to watch a movie on the last day of school. This is 25% of the 6th-grade class. How many total students are in the 6th grade?

SubTopics: Use the coordinate plane to solve real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: Ashley drew the triangle LMN on the grid below.
problems/NC18G6M/media/28a.jpg
What is the area of triangle LMN?

SubTopics: Determine the measure of center of a data set and understand that it is a single number that summarizes all the values of that data set.
Content: This table shows the number of minutes Carol and Anna walked each day for 5 days.
problems/NC18G6M/media/29a.jpg
Which statement is true?

A.Choice: Carol's mean for the number of minutes she walked is equal to her median.

B.Choice: Carol's mean for the number of minutes she walked is greater than Anna's mean.

C.Choice: Anna's median for the number of minutes she walked is greater than her mean.

D.Choice: Anna's mean for the number of minutes she walked is equal to Carol's mean.

SubTopics: Understand the concept of a ratio and use ratio language.
Content: A restaurant orders corn tortillas and flour tortillas. The ratio of the number of corn tortillas to the number of flour tortillas is 2 : 3. What is the ratio of the number of flour tortillas to the total number of tortillas?

SubTopics: Use ratio reasoning with equivalent whole-number ratios to solve real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: In the table, the ratio of y to x is constant.
problems/NC18G6M/media/31a.jpg
What is the value of the missing number?

SubTopics: Determine the measure of center of a data set and understand that it is a single number that summarizes all the values of that data set.
Content: The table shows the daily amount that Trevor spent on snacks.
problems/NC18G6M/media/32a.jpg
During which week did Trevor spend a mean amount of $0.85 per day on snacks?

SubTopics: Understand the concept of a ratio and use ratio language.
Content: A set of stickers contains 4 hearts for every 6 stars. Which choice contains an equivalent ratio of hearts to stars?

SubTopics: Analyze center and variability.
Content: A list of numbers is shown.
What is the mean of the list of numbers?

SubTopics: Use substitution to determine whether a given number in a specified set makes an equation true.
Content: Which value from the set {1/2, 2/3, 4/3, 5/2} is a value of x that will make the equation 3/4 ÷ x = 9/8 true?

SubTopics: Apply and extend previous understandings of the volume of a right rectangular prism to find the volume of right rectangular prisms with fractional edge lengths. Apply this understanding to the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: A right rectangular prism is shown.
problems/NC18G6M/media/36a.jpg
What is the volume of the prism?

SubTopics: Use variables to represent numbers and write expressions when solving a real-world or mathematical problem.
Content: Jason owns a party supply store.

:ibox:• He sells balloons for $0.50 each and party hats for $1.25 each.

• Jason buys each balloon for $0.10 and each party hat for $0.20.
Which expression represents how much money Jason gains from selling n balloons and h party hats?

SubTopics: Use ratio reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems with percents.
Content: Sarah earns $400 per week and spends 15% of her earnings on transportation. How much does Sarah spend on transportation every week?

SubTopics: Represent right prisms and right pyramids using nets made up of rectangles and triangles, and use the nets to find the surface area of these figures. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: Karen has a cube that has a side length of 6 in. The net of the cube is shown.
problems/NC18G6M/media/39a.jpg
What is the surface area of the cube?

SubTopics: Understand and use prime factorization and the relationships between factors.
Content: Which expression is equal to 48 + 72?

SubTopics: Use ratio reasoning with equivalent whole-number ratios to solve real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: A store sells cans of tomatoes priced as shown.
problems/NC18G6M/media/41a.jpg
Which size can of tomatoes has the lowest cost per ounce?

SubTopics: Use ratio reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems with percents.
Content: If 45% of a number, n, is 225, what is 74% of n?

SubTopics: Display numerical data in plots on a number line.
Content: A researcher was interested in how much Vitamin C adults had in their daily diets.

:ibox:• The researcher surveyed 100 random adults.

• She made a box plot based on the amounts of Vitamin C in the diets of the 100 adults.
problems/NC18G6M/media/43a.jpg
What percent of those in the survey get at least 90 milligrams of Vitamin C?

SubTopics: Use ratio reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems with percents.
Content: At a middle school, 74 students have freckles. There are 258 students in the school. To the nearest tenth of a percent, what percent of the students have freckles?

SubTopics: Use ratio reasoning with equivalent whole-number ratios to solve real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: A motorcycle can go 50 miles using one gallon of gas. ABOUT how many gallons of gas will be used to go 150 kilometers?
(Note: 1 mile is approximately 1.6 kilometers.)
